Plato de San Miguel ($13.95) - Thin New York steak, sausage, fried plantain and fresh cheese

Pollo Frito ($11.95) - Fried Chicken

Entrees are served with rice, black beans, beet salad, and tortillas.

Overall the food was delicious.  As a family we shared everything, and our daughter happily devoured the tamale and fried chicken.  

Great family run restaurant. Service was fast and very friendly. 

The only thing that didn't go over well was the Horchata.  Our 4 year old loves them (for the usual high sugar content), haha.  This one wasn't very sweet, so depends on your tastebuds.

We look forward to coming back and trying other Guatemalan dishes.

They are currently CASH ONLY with plans to accept credit cards in the coming weeks.

excerpts:
Guatemalan style fried plantain and fresh cheese)

- RELLENITOS DE PLATANO (Mashes banana plantain with black beans inside)

- PLATANOS EN MOLE (Banana plantain with special sweet brown (chocolate) sauce)
beans.author: Mari S.
beans.review:
San Miguel is a family owned Guatemalan restaurant located on Mission St. in the neighborhood bordering the Outer Mission and Bernal Heights.

It has been awhile, so this review is a bit overdue. Dined on a Sunday evening and ordered the following...

- CHUCHITOS (Small corn tamale with chicken inside)

- CAMARONES ASADOS (Charbroiled Prawns with "Chimichurri" sauce)

- MOJARRA FRITA (Fresh fried Tilapia fish)

- CAK-ICK (Authentic special chicken soup)

- PLATO DE SAN MIGUEL (New york steak, pork sausage, Guatemalan style fried plantain and fresh cheese)

- RELLENITOS DE PLATANO (Mashes banana plantain with black beans inside)

- PLATANOS EN MOLE (Banana plantain with special sweet brown (chocolate) sauce)

I very much enjoyed my meal, the ambiance, and homey feeling this restaurant conveys. Would definitely come back and highly recommend for Guatemalan food in the city.

excerpts: Served with super velvety black beans, deliciously rice, and tortillas.
So freaking good!
beans.author: Wayne S.
beans.review: Whoo this place is the bomb.com! So good. I'm a huge Latin cuisine fan but have never had Guatemalan food before. I assumed it was similar to Mexican or Salvadorian but man was I in for a surprise. I was able to speak to the Chef Juliano, super nice guy, and he mentioned they used to have a food truck and had been on Food Network. After that, I was like tell me what to eat and I'll eat it, his recommendation was Adobvada, which is made with pork shoulder. I was a little hesitant because I'm not into pork but oh boy am I glad I got that. The exterior of this dish is super crunchy giving it an incredible texture, almost like really good fried chicken. Served with super velvety black beans, deliciously rice, and tortillas. So freaking good!

excerpts: There were three tamales with a side of beans and cream.
beans.author: Laura S.
beans.review: We stopped here thinking it was a Mexican Restaurant because it said mayan kitchen, for some reason we thought it was Mexican, it was a surprise to know it was a Guatemalan Restaurant. My first impression was "wow, is so clean and well organized for such a small place" its cleaner that most of the restaurants plus the costumer service is excellent, I don't recall going to another restaurant and being serve like i did there. the owners kids are so well educated and know how to serve. there was a little girl who would come every few minutes to check if we needed anything else and she was so polite and well spoken for her age. due to the fact that i don't know anything about the Guatemala cuisine, It took me a while to choose what to eat. initially, i wanted the enchiladas but one of the waitress told me that the enchiladas were not the typical enchiladas but a tostada. she educate me on every dish, and at the end i decided to get the tamales. There were three tamales with a side of beans and cream. They were delicious, plus el agua de horchata was the best, its on the sweet side but i love sweet so I loved it. When we were almost ready to leave the sweet little girl brought us fruit which where on the house. Overall, i had an amazing experience at this place, it made me feel at home, everyone was super nice and welcoming. The food was delicious and costumer service was excellent!

excerpts: 6 total, 2 guacamole, 2 beans, 2 salsa topped with onions and spicy salsa on the side.
beans.author: Annie D.
beans.review:
Came to this place at around noon hoping for a great experience and i did! I loved it! The smell of the restaurant was like the smell from home. It didn't smell like grease like other restaurants. 
I was confused when i walked in because i wasn't sure whether to wait to be seated or just pick a spot. 

Anyway, the lady who served my table (1 other person with me) was very nice. She did everything, took our order, drinks, and bussed our table. 

We ordered tostadas which were delicious. 6 total, 2 guacamole, 2 beans, 2 salsa topped with onions and spicy salsa on the side. 

We ordered plato san miguel which is number 30. I highly recommend this plate because it wasnt overwhelming and still filled me up. 
Ordered horchata and famosa beer. 

Everything was nice and clean. Definitely coming back~

excerpts: The beans and the radish made it even better.
The beans and the tortillas were tasty and good.
I also love the decorations in the restaurant, it's so adorable and so Guatemalan!
beans.author: Marilynnn G.
beans.review: I love la Carne Asada! The beans and the radish made it even better. The beans and the tortillas were tasty and good. I also love the decorations in the restaurant, it's so adorable and so Guatemalan!

excerpts: The rice is really good and the black beans just hit the spot.
Then we got some platanos with beans and crema and it was delicious.
Also ordered a banana milkshake and it tasted just like home.
I was in heaven and would go back once a week if I could.
Cash only!
beans.author: Alexis G.
beans.review:
One of the best things I've found in SF! It was a little piece of home.
Delicious, authentic Guatemalan food.
Ordered hilachas which was super delicious. The rice is really good and the black beans just hit the spot.
Then we got some platanos with beans and crema and it was delicious. Also ordered a banana milkshake and it tasted just like home. I was in heaven and would go back once a week if I could.
Cash only!

excerpts: we spilt a plate with beef, a house-made sausage, rice, plantains, a small wedge of cojita, a log of beans that actually looked EXACTLY like a big dog poop (
sorry but its true, once i said it, neither if us could look at it, let alone eat it AND some spaghetti thing on top
(HUH? spaghetti??).
beans.author: Amy W.
beans.review:
This place - I wanted to love it - service was great - but it was just weird.

We ordered a LARGE beer and it came in a bamboo glass - which might have been kinda cool - but the glass smelled funny and I'm not so certain you can clean bamboo like you can glass so it kinda grossed me out.

We ordered the taquitos - which were the best thing we ordered.  we also got a stuffed pepper appetizer which was fair.  Then we ordered 2 tamales which my bf thought were okay I thought they were gross, kinda slimy masa and flavorless to boot.  

Entree we spilt a plate with beef, a house-made sausage, rice, plantains, a small wedge of cojita, a log of beans that actually looked EXACTLY like a big dog poop (sorry but its true, once i said it, neither if us could look at it, let alone eat it AND some spaghetti thing on top (HUH? spaghetti??).  Served with some small not-homemade corn tortillas.

Sorry, this place just missed the mark for me, I guess I can see how people could like it, I just didn't.

Oh we had a Scoutmob and paid $40 with tip (which included a $15 discount)

excerpts: I was not a huge fan of the chicken or refried beans.
They were not necessarily poor quality, I just did not like the flavor.
beans.author: Owen J.
beans.review:
The beat salad was incredible.  I would go back for more of that.
I was not a huge fan of the chicken or refried beans.  They were not necessarily poor quality, I just did not like the flavor.

excerpts: French roll with black beans was good and kept me full despite the underwhelming main.
beans.author: Jason B.
beans.review:
Those things.

Good things by musical Miguel: http://youtu.be/47bFAmk5-Bo

Disappointing things by culinary Miguel: Traditional Guatemalan pepian.

Homemade seed sauce gave this chicken and vegetable stew a unique flavor. Slightly sweet. Slightly spicy. Lighter than mole. Different.

Where they lost me (and the third start) was the menu. Inside and online it claims two pieces of chicken. Only got one. Was told that's how it comes now.

All fine and good but you need to update your menu.

Might be more forgiving had it been the greatest thing ever. But it wasn't. And not very filling unless you want to eat all 10 small tortillas that come on the side.

Fortunately had another Guatemalan tradition to start. French roll with black beans was good and kept me full despite the underwhelming main.

Service was nice and the space was very Latin America inspired. With an average rating of four stars might have just gone on an off day.

Either way I don't plan on coming back for more things.

excerpts: I personally love the New York steak (great flavors and served with beans, rice, and pasta), the seafood soup, the taquitos, and the shrimp appetizer (tostaditos de cerviche).
All these dishes are very fresh.
My husband
beans.author: L L.
beans.review:
This is a great little place if you are looking for some authentic Guatemalan food.  I think you have to know what dishes to pick, though.  I personally love the New York steak (great flavors and served with beans, rice, and pasta), the seafood soup, the taquitos, and the shrimp appetizer (tostaditos de cerviche).  All these dishes are very fresh.  My husband and I end up ordering these pretty much every time.  

Because of the quality of food and authentic flavors, I will give this place 5 stars.  The downside is that it's cash only, which can be quite a pain for dinner.

excerpts: I love their black beans, taquitos, and their guacamole is to die for.
For entrees, I love the grilled chicken (not sure what it is called) and garlic shrimp with steak.
beans.author: Milly H.
beans.review:
The restaurant gives you a very comfortable feeling when you walk in. The walls and ceiling are decorated with little pieces of Guatemalan trinkets and art. I had (and still have) so much fun staring at the unique pieces.

The food is delicious. I love their black beans, taquitos, and their guacamole is to die for. For entrees, I love the grilled chicken (not sure what it is called) and garlic shrimp with steak. OMG, talking about it makes me wanna go there and eat right now. 

The family that owns this place make you feel like you are part of the family when you're there. Great customer service. 

Don't forget to order their fresh made smoothies (almost taste like dessert in a cup!) Their coffee is a good way to wind down their dinner. Every time I go, I leave stuffed. 

Prices are very reasonable for what they give you. Tons of authentic Guatemalan food!

Anytime I'm in the area, I head down to San Miguel.

excerpts: L ordered the chicken in mole which was served with rice, beans, and beets.
He was very pleased with the dish.
beans.author: Rob L.
beans.review:
AN OASIS IN THE MISSION DISTRICT SERVING AUTHENTIC GUATAMALAN FOOD

We opened the sliding door and entered this cozy and cute restaurant on a cold and rainy evening.  Plants and wooden carvings hanging from the tin-roof ceiling add atmosphere to the dining room.  The friendly server came over to greet us and took our order in Spanish.  She brought us sliced pineapple and watermelon to begin the meal.

Chicken Pepian
Boneless pieces of chicken were immersed in an intoxicating earthy broth made from chilies, tomatillos, and seeds.  Rice and homemade corn tortillas were served on the side.  This dish exceeded my expectations!

Chicken Mole
L ordered the chicken in mole which was served with rice, beans, and beets.  He was very pleased with the dish.  I tasted the mole and it was on the sweet side but tasted very good.

The salsa served on the side is spicy and flavorful.  We were very pleased with the attentive service; it was like having a homemade meal.

excerpts: If you order certain entrees, they are served with a side of refried black beans, queso, platanos y crema.
Refried black beans...mmmm!
beans.author: Ken B.
beans.review:
Great service, delicious food.  What else could you want?
If you order certain entrees, they are served with a side of refried black beans, queso, platanos y crema.  Refried black beans...mmmm!

I had the hilachas this time.  Sort of a thick beef stew with shredded meat (instead of cubed,) carrots, potatoes & tomatillo in a hearty tomato-based gravy.

Don't be afraid to try the habanero salsa.  It's got a kick to it, but it shouldn't leave you burning.

excerpts: We shared chicken tamales as an app, which came with crema and black beans - delicious.
For my entree, I had the tostadas, which had a great crunch and savory quality to them.
beans.author: Carissa R.
beans.review:
We're moving to Outer Noe in the next few weeks and had a moment two nights ago when exploring the new 'hood where we realized that the Outer Mission is just a few minutes walk from our place. After years of living in the lower pac heights/J-town area, it's like being a new city! And a new city means a whole new slew of restaurants. Including San Miguel, where I had eaten once prior with friends and now know is only a 5 minute walk from our apartment. 

After that long (somewhat uninteresting intro), I have to say that I wasn't sure what to expect from Guatemalan cuisine. I have never been to Guatemala, nor do I know anyone Guatemalan. I was very pleasantly surprised. We shared chicken tamales as an app, which came with crema and black beans - delicious. For my entree, I had the tostadas, which had a great crunch and savory quality to them. The boyfriend loves the steak entree (has ordered it the two times we've been there). 

The service was friendly and always persistent in refilling our waters. One of my favorite qualities. 

If I rated restaurants based on the quality of their restrooms, this one would not do so well, with a hole in the floorboard and one of those old cloth towel dispensers on a wheel for drying your hands (needless to say I used my jeans instead). But I don't generally take it into too much consideration because what I care about is food & service, which were both great.

excerpts: Over time, however, I've been disappointed perhaps because I compare what I order with my mom's or Abuelita's dishes, or just because I no longer enjoy what I order because things are always too salty: the beans, the sauces, the mole, longanizas, etc.
Today, unfortunately, was not any different although I was hopeful.
I ordered the soap de gallina criolla (hen soup) and barely touched it because it was too salty!
The same thing goes for the soap de pata, which my husband order; and even after adding hot water to our soup bowls to cut the salt we couldn't make any progress on it.
I seriously doubt that we will return based on this experience.
Bummer!
beans.author: Maria E.
beans.review: When San Miguel first opened I was a happy camper!  I looked forward to eating the food from my homeland and was impressed. Over time, however, I've been disappointed perhaps because I compare what I order with my mom's or Abuelita's dishes, or just because I no longer enjoy what I order because things are always too salty: the beans, the sauces, the mole, longanizas, etc. Today, unfortunately, was not any different although I was hopeful.  I ordered the soap de gallina criolla (hen soup) and barely touched it because it was too salty!  The same thing goes for the soap de pata, which my husband order; and even after adding hot water to our soup bowls to cut the salt we couldn't make any progress on it.  I seriously doubt that we will return based on this experience. Bummer!

excerpts: I had some combination plate that came with a steak, sausage, beans, rice, salad and plantains.
Man for a moment
I flashed back to when i was a lil' kid getting ready for dinner when I used to live with my grandma.
The food was so flavorful but no overwhelming.
the steak was juicy and tender which made me eat as slowly as possible savoring every bite.
beans.author: Alfredo N.
beans.review:
I'm part Guatemalan and had the pleasure to have grown up eating dishes that both my Mom and Grandma cooked.

Guatemalans are not huge in numbers here as Mexicans so it isn't as easy to come across a place that knows how to make tasty good quality food. I was riding shotgun one late night down mission and I caught a glimpse of the little sign (Before they hung up the banner) and said i wanted to come back and try. for weeks later I tried to find this place but for the life of me could not. then as usual as it most of the time is me and the GF stumbled upon it as we were looking for parking to go to some other spot. So we had to try it.

I had some combination plate that came with a steak, sausage, beans, rice, salad and plantains. Man for a moment I flashed back to when i was a lil' kid getting ready for dinner when I used to live with my grandma. The food was so flavorful but no overwhelming. the steak was juicy and tender which made me eat as slowly as possible savoring every bite. the sausage was also great but for the size and price i wish they would have thrown another one in. 

I enjoyed the decor as it had all these pictures and curiosities from Guatemala. I'm glad I was able to finally try this place. Here is where I will return when i miss being a kid and getting home cooked meals.

excerpts: Also the whole plate was sort of a mess I thought because the chicken mole was served with black beans rice and queso.
beans.author: Jose U.
beans.review:
I'm from Guatemala and grew up with my mom making stuff like Pepian, rabo (oxtail), tamales, sopa de res, hilachas etc. So I really want to like this place. The service is good, very attentive. But the food can be hit or miss. The first time I came here, I came with a friend and we tried the ceviche. It tasted nice and fresh, it was pretty good. Also had the Pepian, the sauce for it was good but I was disappointed that they made it with chicken.
The second time I came it was with my parents. They ordered the sopa de res and were pretty happy with it and they have discerning taste for that sort of thing. I decided to try the mole and it wasn't very good I'm sorry to report. I'm not sure if mole is supposed to be so chocolaty...the chicken was sort of bland and chewy. Also the whole plate was sort of a mess I thought because the chicken mole was served with black beans rice and queso. It was just all over the place in terms of flavors.

 My dad ordered platanos en mole and there the chocolaty sauce complemented the plantains very well.

I would definitely recommend the Pepian, and will try the sopa de res. Unfortunately they don't make rabo :(

The place looks clean, but it's kind of small and to add to the ambiance they play marimba music and videos of Guatemalan music. The place is definitely not good for large groups or even medium ones, four people per group tops. Parking is tough in the neighborhood and it's CASH ONLY :(

excerpts: Rellenitos de platano (mashed plantain paste filled with fried beans and then itself fried) were awesome and unhealthy as expected.
It would be also nice if besides rellenitos de platano they also offered simply sliced fried plantain with fried beans on the side as well, or fried banana.
It would be also nice if besides rellenitos de platano they also offered simply sliced fried plantain with fried beans on the side as well, or fried banana.
beans.author: Osberto M.
beans.review:
I've eaten here a few times within the last two months.  I was born and raised in Guatemala, and have had these dishes all my life both at home and outside.

In my opinion, the 'caldo de res' (a simple but really tasty beef stock with beef chunks and vegetables in it) is 5 stars, and the 'caq-ik'  (Q'eqchi language name for the dish) is worth 3 1/2. I am not used to having the caq-ik broth be this thick.  As far as I am concerned caq-ik is meant to be just like caldo de res in terms of consistency, but perhaps this varies. Either way, I think I remember a more intense flavor. 

Rellenitos de platano (mashed plantain paste filled with fried beans and then itself fried) were awesome and unhealthy as expected. 

Their menu could be richer. I don't think I saw 'pollo en jocon', 'saq-ik', 'caldo de gallina', 'salpicon de panza', and such things. It would also be great if they had thick, handmade corn tortillas, but these hardly appear anywhere I go so I cannot hold it against them. It would be also nice if besides rellenitos de platano they also offered simply sliced fried plantain with fried beans on the side as well, or fried banana. All of it may seem redundant but they are good in their own special ways.

Service is friendly but slow, they will take time to bring the beer (they have some of the Guatemalan beers there, for the curious), the food and the bill.  They do check on you to see if you are missing tortillas for your meal, and they also offer a couple of courtesy melon slices some times.

Finally, the thing that really goes against them is the aspect of the place. Poorly lit, smells like fish (hopefully from the fish dishes they serve), somewhat shabby. They could improve a lot on this and that would get them 4 starts. Don't be misled, the fishy smell at the entrance has very little relation to how good the caldo de res is.  Plus, they have some very folksy Guatemalan music playing complete with videos of the bands, so you get to see that too.

excerpts: The Black beans are so good and the plantains stuffed with black beans are the perfect way to end the meal.
beans.author: Vicky C.
beans.review:
Joe S. if you didn't like it the first time I strongly urge you to go again. 

The Black beans are so good and the plantains stuffed with black beans are the perfect way to end the meal.  Great for wanting something deep fried, but not too heavy that you feel bloated.

I love love love the food there!!!!! Everytime I'm in the neighborhood I always make everyone eat there.

excerpts: First, the good: the tortillas were great, the horchata was pretty tasty, I liked the black beans, and the service was excellent.
beans.author: Lisa K.
beans.review: I guess I ordered the wrong things here. First, the good: the tortillas were great, the horchata was pretty tasty, I liked the black beans, and the service was excellent. I got the vegetarian plate, which was mainly just bland, from the baked plantain to the rice to the plain, boiled vegetables. I wouldn't get it again. The pepian chicken had a tasty sauce but the chicken seemed to be full of gristle and odds and ends, and had a kinda of odd, chewy texture. I wouldn't be too encouraged to get any of the other chicken dishes from this, especially since I didn't find the menu to be very descriptive. But, I might give the beef dishes a try based on other reviews.

excerpts: (I had a delicious chicken dish with a creamy tomato sauce and a side of refried black beans) and the prices are extremely reasonable.
beans.author: Allison S.
beans.review: This cozy little Guatemalan restaurant is well worth the trek to the outer, outer Mission.  The food is good (I had a delicious chicken dish with a creamy tomato sauce and a side of refried black beans) and the prices are extremely reasonable.

excerpts: It's basically a cold beef salad with orange juice, mint, onions, cilantro and onions and  served with soft and crunchy tortillas, rice and beans.
It was perfect with the HOT salsa.
We also tried the chilitos rellenos and plantanos.
everything was great!
beans.author: Erick A.
beans.review: I walked by this place, scanned the menu and found something that sounded perfect for this hot day in the city... Salpicon Beef.  mmmm.  It's basically a cold beef salad with orange juice, mint, onions, cilantro and onions and  served with soft and crunchy tortillas, rice and beans.  It was perfect with the HOT salsa.  We also tried the chilitos rellenos and plantanos.  everything was great!

excerpts: well seasoned, juicy meat and the black beans, cheese, grilled onions, grilled green onions and spicy salsa...
damn.
so good.
beans.author: jenny t.
beans.review:
six years ago, when it was located in the mission, my friends and i randomly found this place after volunteering at AIDS walk.  i moved back to chicago, but my friends made it an annual post AIDS walk tradition as well as a bi monthly let's-go-get-that-good-pork-dish tradition.  i nearly cried last year when i was visiting SF and san miguel wasn't where i remembered it.  i thought that i would only have the memory of that amazing pork to get me by until i found a comparable guatamalan restaurant. 

but then, i was hanging out in the mission and saw a cart with the san miguel logo on it.  and i nearly cried when i found out that san miguel exists in bernal heights.

i went yesterday.  and the pork was as delicious as i remembered.  the plantains were tasty.  service was quick and friendly.  we also got the steak with the pork sausage.  yum!  well seasoned, juicy meat and the black beans, cheese, grilled onions, grilled green onions and spicy salsa...  damn.  so good.  and very decently priced.  

i only have another week in the city before i move back to chicago.  i'll be eating there at least two more times before i go.

excerpts: Order this appetizer, which consists of salty dry refried black beans, queso fresco, super hot salsa and crispy housemade tortilla chips, and prepare to cry with pleasure.
Great tamales and stews, too.
beans.author: Eric W.
beans.review: Two words:  Frijoles Volteados!  Order this appetizer, which consists of salty dry refried black beans, queso fresco, super hot salsa and crispy housemade tortilla chips, and prepare to cry with pleasure.  Great tamales and stews, too.

excerpts: We ordered the fried plantains, but she mistakenly brought us the plantains stuffed with black beans.
That was no good.
We brought her attention to her error, and she brought us the plantains.
They were decent.
The shrimp appetizer was great.
That was by far the best thing.
Of the entrees, 2 were okay, 1 was inedible.
I think there are probably some great dishes here...
I'd like to give them the benefit of the doubt.
But based on what we did order, I wouldn't recommend this place.
beans.author: Joe S.
beans.review: You need to know what to order here.  The service was friendly but slow.  We ordered the fried plantains, but she mistakenly brought us the plantains stuffed with black beans.  That was no good.  We brought her attention to her error, and she brought us the plantains.  They were decent.  The shrimp appetizer was great.  That was by far the best thing.  Of the entrees, 2 were okay, 1 was inedible.  I think there are probably some great dishes here... I'd like to give them the benefit of the doubt.  But based on what we did order, I wouldn't recommend this place.

excerpts: san miguel plate is really good, it comes with a tasty steak, beans, rice, and plantains.
I pretty much like everything.
beans.author: perla P.
beans.review: The best Guatemalan food I have eaten in the bay so far. I love this place, their decoration and customer service is great. For apetizer I like tostaditas ( I think that's the name) san miguel plate is really good, it comes with a tasty steak, beans, rice, and plantains. I pretty much like everything.

excerpts: I recently came back from a month in Guatemala and was seriously missing plaintains, refried black beans, and Guatemalan fresh cheese, and was quite happy to see them at San Miguel Restaurant in their "Plato de San Miguel."
Now, the beans and plaintains were not exactly as good as they were in Xela, Antigua, or even touristy Panajachel, but they were more than good enough.
(The people next to us had a plate of "tostadas," which are actually called "tacos" or "enchiladas" in Guatemala, I've already forgotten which, which looked pretty good.)
They also have actual Guatemalan beer there -- including the omnipresent "Gallo" beer, which is called "Famosa" here to avoid confusion with a certain line of cheap wines.

Unlike another Central American restaurant in the Mission, Poc Chuc, San Miguel is very down-home, folks from the community eat there, and the server spoke Spanish to me even though I don't exactly jump out as looking like a Spanish speaker -- which is great, since I need every chance I can to work on my marginal Spanish.
beans.author: moosedog i.
beans.review: Somebody please tell me if I'm wrong, but I think this is the only Guatemalan restaurant in San Francisco, as in serving only (or at least a fair amount of) Guatemalan food.  I recently came back from a month in Guatemala and was seriously missing plaintains, refried black beans, and Guatemalan fresh cheese, and was quite happy to see them at San Miguel Restaurant in their "Plato de San Miguel."  Now, the beans and plaintains were not exactly as good as they were in Xela, Antigua, or even touristy Panajachel, but they were more than good enough.  (The people next to us had a plate of "tostadas," which are actually called "tacos" or "enchiladas" in Guatemala, I've already forgotten which, which looked pretty good.)  They also have actual Guatemalan beer there -- including the omnipresent "Gallo" beer, which is called "Famosa" here to avoid confusion with a certain line of cheap wines.  Unlike another Central American restaurant in the Mission, Poc Chuc, San Miguel is very down-home, folks from the community eat there, and the server spoke Spanish to me even though I don't exactly jump out as looking like a Spanish speaker -- which is great, since I need every chance I can to work on my marginal Spanish.

excerpts: Order this appetizer, which consists of salty dry refried black beans, queso fresco, super hot salsa and crispy housemade tortilla chips, and prepare to cry with pleasure.
Great tamales and stews, too.
queso fresco.author: Eric W.
queso fresco.review: Two words:  Frijoles Volteados!  Order this appetizer, which consists of salty dry refried black beans, queso fresco, super hot salsa and crispy housemade tortilla chips, and prepare to cry with pleasure.  Great tamales and stews, too.

excerpts:
Guatemalan style fried plantain and fresh cheese)

- RELLENITOS DE PLATANO (Mashes banana plantain with black beans inside)

- PLATANOS EN MOLE (Banana plantain with special sweet brown (chocolate) sauce)
rellenitos de platano.author: Mari S.
rellenitos de platano.review:
San Miguel is a family owned Guatemalan restaurant located on Mission St. in the neighborhood bordering the Outer Mission and Bernal Heights.

It has been awhile, so this review is a bit overdue. Dined on a Sunday evening and ordered the following...

- CHUCHITOS (Small corn tamale with chicken inside)

- CAMARONES ASADOS (Charbroiled Prawns with "Chimichurri" sauce)

- MOJARRA FRITA (Fresh fried Tilapia fish)

- CAK-ICK (Authentic special chicken soup)

- PLATO DE SAN MIGUEL (New york steak, pork sausage, Guatemalan style fried plantain and fresh cheese)

- RELLENITOS DE PLATANO (Mashes banana plantain with black beans inside)

- PLATANOS EN MOLE (Banana plantain with special sweet brown (chocolate) sauce)

I very much enjoyed my meal, the ambiance, and homey feeling this restaurant conveys. Would definitely come back and highly recommend for Guatemalan food in the city.

rellenitos de platano.author: Osberto M.
rellenitos de platano.review:
I've eaten here a few times within the last two months.  I was born and raised in Guatemala, and have had these dishes all my life both at home and outside.

In my opinion, the 'caldo de res' (a simple but really tasty beef stock with beef chunks and vegetables in it) is 5 stars, and the 'caq-ik'  (Q'eqchi language name for the dish) is worth 3 1/2. I am not used to having the caq-ik broth be this thick.  As far as I am concerned caq-ik is meant to be just like caldo de res in terms of consistency, but perhaps this varies. Either way, I think I remember a more intense flavor. 

Rellenitos de platano (mashed plantain paste filled with fried beans and then itself fried) were awesome and unhealthy as expected. 

Their menu could be richer. I don't think I saw 'pollo en jocon', 'saq-ik', 'caldo de gallina', 'salpicon de panza', and such things. It would also be great if they had thick, handmade corn tortillas, but these hardly appear anywhere I go so I cannot hold it against them. It would be also nice if besides rellenitos de platano they also offered simply sliced fried plantain with fried beans on the side as well, or fried banana. All of it may seem redundant but they are good in their own special ways.

Service is friendly but slow, they will take time to bring the beer (they have some of the Guatemalan beers there, for the curious), the food and the bill.  They do check on you to see if you are missing tortillas for your meal, and they also offer a couple of courtesy melon slices some times.

Finally, the thing that really goes against them is the aspect of the place. Poorly lit, smells like fish (hopefully from the fish dishes they serve), somewhat shabby. They could improve a lot on this and that would get them 4 starts. Don't be misled, the fishy smell at the entrance has very little relation to how good the caldo de res is.  Plus, they have some very folksy Guatemalan music playing complete with videos of the bands, so you get to see that too.

excerpts: My dad ordered platanos en mole and there the chocolaty sauce complemented the plantains very well.
platanos en mole.author: Jose U.
platanos en mole.review:
I'm from Guatemala and grew up with my mom making stuff like Pepian, rabo (oxtail), tamales, sopa de res, hilachas etc. So I really want to like this place. The service is good, very attentive. But the food can be hit or miss. The first time I came here, I came with a friend and we tried the ceviche. It tasted nice and fresh, it was pretty good. Also had the Pepian, the sauce for it was good but I was disappointed that they made it with chicken.
The second time I came it was with my parents. They ordered the sopa de res and were pretty happy with it and they have discerning taste for that sort of thing. I decided to try the mole and it wasn't very good I'm sorry to report. I'm not sure if mole is supposed to be so chocolaty...the chicken was sort of bland and chewy. Also the whole plate was sort of a mess I thought because the chicken mole was served with black beans rice and queso. It was just all over the place in terms of flavors.

 My dad ordered platanos en mole and there the chocolaty sauce complemented the plantains very well.

I would definitely recommend the Pepian, and will try the sopa de res. Unfortunately they don't make rabo :(

The place looks clean, but it's kind of small and to add to the ambiance they play marimba music and videos of Guatemalan music. The place is definitely not good for large groups or even medium ones, four people per group tops. Parking is tough in the neighborhood and it's CASH ONLY :(
